quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you're really open and open source, sometimes you have to stand up the bullies and you have to fight to protect your open source ideals.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A values-based operating principle for open-source leaders: openness sometimes requires active defense, not passive neutrality.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Previously, 1% of the world thought I was terrible and now I feel like it's up to four or 5%.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing of backlash as a shift in visibility/scale rather than a total collapse in reputation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: A lie gets around the world seven times before the truth has time to get out of bed.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for crisis communications: misinformation spreads faster than corrections, so plan accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Matt is the co-creator of WordPress, which powers 40% of websites on the internet today, including whitehouse.gov.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that contextualizes why governance and brand/trademark disputes can have outsized impact.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and skim provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (WorkOS)
quotes.context: A practical expectation-setting reminder to plan for enterprise requirements as your SaaS matures.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (WorkOS)
quotes.context: Highlights a build-vs-buy productivity heuristic: choose tools that minimize cognitive load and time-to-ship.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Warrant's product is based on a groundbreaking authorization system called Zanzibar, which was originally designed for Google to power Google Docs and YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (WorkOS)
quotes.context: A concrete example of leveraging proven, large-scale architectures for authorization and access control.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Today we currently help over 9,000 companies including some startup household names like Atlassian, Ramp and LangChain start and scale their security programs and ultimately build trust by automating compliance, centralizing GRC, and accelerating security reviews.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: Provides a scale data point plus a three-part operational model for building trust via security/compliance workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But the idea is with automation, with AI, with software, we are helping customers build trust with prospects and customers in an efficient way.
quotes.speaker: Christina Cacioppo
quotes.context: Frames compliance work as a trust-building lever that can be made efficient through automation and AI.

quotes.topic_title: Matt’s roles: WordPress, Automattic, investing, jazz
quotes.text: It's really interesting seeing WordPress used as an engine for powering things I would say don't even look like a website, which is kind of wild to me, but that's kind of the beauty of the open source people do things with that you don't expect.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Highlights a product strategy advantage of open source: unexpected, user-driven expansion into new use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Matt’s roles: WordPress, Automattic, investing, jazz
quotes.text: And then had this vision where instead of downloading the software and setting up a database and everything, we made a SaaS version of WordPress. I pitched it at CNET, they didn't want to do it, so I was like, "Okay, I got to do this," so I left and started a company called Automatic.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A concrete example of turning an unmet internal pitch into a standalone company by shifting from self-hosted to SaaS.

quotes.topic_title: Matt’s roles: WordPress, Automattic, investing, jazz
quotes.text: so that's now grown to be over 1700 people in actually 90 countries so we've actually been fully distributed and remote and asynchronous from the start, which I think is one of our superpowers.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Actionable operating model: remote + async as a deliberate capability that scales globally.

quotes.topic_title: Matt’s roles: WordPress, Automattic, investing, jazz
quotes.text: Yeah, so when we started, a lot of websites were built on custom CMSs and there's a lot of fragmentation in the space, but now WordPress has grown to be over 40% of all websites in the world, which is 10x the number two, which right now is Shopify.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A striking market-share data point and competitive framing (10x #2) that underscores platform dominance.

quotes.topic_title: Matt’s roles: WordPress, Automattic, investing, jazz
quotes.text: but WordPress is still, because we have this flywheel of open source community, its movements, any open source like Linux or Apache or Wikipedia, it has some positive flywheel effects when it takes off.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Names a defensibility mechanism: an open-source community flywheel that compounds once adoption reaches scale.

quotes.topic_title: WordPress scale and Tumblr moderation challenges
quotes.text: WordPress is still, because we have this flywheel of open source community, its movements, any open source like Linux or Apache or Wikipedia, it has some positive flywheel effects when it takes off.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Highlights the “open source flywheel” as a scalable growth/defensibility model practitioners can intentionally cultivate via community momentum.

quotes.topic_title: WordPress scale and Tumblr moderation challenges
quotes.text: Yeah, running a social network is definitely the hardest thing I've ever attempted.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A blunt prioritization signal for leaders evaluating product complexity and operational risk in social products.

quotes.topic_title: WordPress scale and Tumblr moderation challenges
quotes.text: I thought we knew what we were doing because WordPress ran so much of the web, we dealt with, I thought, every content moderation thing you could ever deal with, but social networks are a whole other ballgame.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson that experience moderating at web scale doesn’t transfer cleanly to social networks, implying different systems, incentives, and abuse patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Bay Lights: public art funding and SF optimism
quotes.text: And then sort of fast-forward, I don't remember the exact timeline, but they were kind of at a final bit of fundraise and they weren't able to close that last bit and I actually mortgaged my condos and donated the last million, million and a half to finish out that project.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A concrete example of taking decisive, high-conviction action to unblock a project at the critical “last mile” of fundraising.

quotes.topic_title: Bay Lights: public art funding and SF optimism
quotes.text: You need to work on the base issues, the fundamentals at the bottom of Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, and then you also have to work on the things that raise your soul a little bit, so arts. So I like that barbell approach to philanthropy.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A memorable “barbell” framework for allocating resources between foundational needs and uplifting, inspirational investments.

quotes.topic_title: Bay Lights: public art funding and SF optimism
quotes.text: They call it impossible works of art. There were like 13 agencies that had to sign off, they were worried the lights would distract birds or seals or environmental reviews, and it was really a lot of public bureaucrats and to make that happen, there was 20 places where someone could have said no and it never would happen.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A vivid operational lesson about navigating complex stakeholder environments where many independent veto points can kill an initiative.

quotes.topic_title: Bay Lights: public art funding and SF optimism
quotes.text: Also in San Francisco, I feel like is entering new chapter right now, going from the doom loop to the boom loop. I'm a big believer in the city.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A concise, contrarian reframe that challenges prevailing pessimism by naming a positive inflection point (“doom loop” to “boom loop”).

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: jazz, economics, and open source ideals
quotes.text: So combining all this philosophy I studied, it felt that open source was actually the most important idea of our generation.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A strong prioritization framework: treat software freedom as a generationally important lever when choosing what to build and advocate for.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: jazz, economics, and open source ideals
quotes.text: If you think about it as more and more of our lives are influenced and actually controlled by the software we use, if we don't have fundamental freedoms attached to that software, we're not truly free.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A contrarian lens for product/tech decisions: user freedom and transparency are prerequisites, not “nice-to-haves,” as software’s control expands.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: jazz, economics, and open source ideals
quotes.text: So WordPress is under license called the GPL, which has four freedoms, the freedom to use the software for any purpose, so we can use it for anything, whether I agree with you or not, the terms of service is you could do whatever you want with it.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A concrete, actionable principle for practitioners: design policies/licenses that preserve broad user autonomy even when you disagree with use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: jazz, economics, and open source ideals
quotes.text: And the GPL has a fun little hack where if you share them, you have to provide those same freedoms to who you share it with.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A memorable mechanism design insight: encode desired community norms (reciprocity) directly into the rules of distribution.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: jazz, economics, and open source ideals
quotes.text: WordPress was actually a fork of abandoned open source project called B2.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A specific example that challenges “start from scratch” instincts: major products can begin by reviving and forking abandoned codebases.

quotes.topic_title: Open source business skepticism and validation
quotes.text: Marc really grilled us, he's like, "How can you build a business on open source? How can you be remote and distributed? Look around Silicon Valley, Google, Microsoft, Oracle, Sun, every great company has had an office. How are you going to build something that can change the internet with people all around the world?"
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A concrete example of the core skepticism practitioners should be ready to rebut when pursuing contrarian theses like open source + remote work.

quotes.topic_title: Open source business skepticism and validation
quotes.text: And just had this long hour long debate and we walked out of that, I was like, "Wow, that was the worst meeting ever. They just hate everything we're doing."
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Highlights how intense pushback can be misread as rejection, a useful warning for founders in high-stakes validation moments.

quotes.topic_title: Open source business skepticism and validation
quotes.text: And then the next day they were like, "Hey, we're interested." I was like, "What happened?"
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Shows that apparent “bad meetings” can still convert, encouraging teams to separate emotional reaction from actual signal.

quotes.topic_title: Open source business skepticism and validation
quotes.text: I didn't realize that he had this idea where he wanted to attack the ideas and see how we defended it was how they battle tested things.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A practical mental model: treat aggressive questioning as a deliberate stress test of strategy, not personal opposition.

quotes.topic_title: Why Llama is “fake open source”
quotes.text: And so that does not give you the freedom to use the software for any purpose. If at some point you have to ask for permission, you're kind of at the whims of this company who you might be aligned with or you might be an enemy with.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A crisp litmus test for practitioners: if usage requires permission at scale, it fails the core open-source freedom principle and introduces strategic dependency risk.

quotes.topic_title: Why Llama is “fake open source”
quotes.text: And also, how do you define that? So, for example, on WordPress, our products don't have 750 million monthly active registered users, but we reach billions of people per month in terms of visitors. So, is that defined? So, there's just ambiguity there.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Highlights a practical due-diligence checklist item: ambiguous thresholds (MAUs vs visitors) can create hidden compliance and licensing risk.

quotes.topic_title: Why Llama is “fake open source”
quotes.text: My best guess now, I don't have any inside information here, but I think they're calling it open source because there's some European regulation about open source versus proprietary AI models.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A contrarian hypothesis that “open source” labeling may be driven by regulatory incentives rather than licensing reality—useful for interpreting vendor messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Why Llama is “fake open source”
quotes.text: It's incumbent on us to make open source, to make a better user experience, to make a better product so that people choose it, and then the world becomes more free, not less free.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: An actionable strategy for open-source builders: adoption comes from superior UX/product, not ideology, and that’s what advances freedom at scale.

quotes.topic_title: AI trained on open source and how to contribute
quotes.text: That's beautiful. It's one of the safest things to train on, right, because the license of open source very explicitly allows that.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A clear licensing-based mental model for why open-source code is uniquely low-risk training data for AI models.

quotes.topic_title: AI trained on open source and how to contribute
quotes.text: And if you fast forward like 50 or 100, I do believe that the utility for proprietary software eventually approaches zero.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A contrarian long-term view that reframes open source as the enduring substrate of future technology, not just a development approach.

quotes.topic_title: AI trained on open source and how to contribute
quotes.text: And so I really hope that more and more people... I'm a little bit of an evangelist here. I'm a missionary, where I really want to encourage more and more people to consider at least making part of their time, even if just a few hours a week, contributing to open source because you could be part of something that is a huge impact.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Actionable advice to allocate a small, consistent time budget to open source as a high-leverage way to create outsized impact.

quotes.topic_title: AI trained on open source and how to contribute
quotes.text: Yeah, pick a project that you use or like. That's obviously a nice one.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for choosing where to contribute that increases motivation and domain familiarity.

quotes.topic_title: AI trained on open source and how to contribute
quotes.text: So, really whatever your talent is, there's people who translate, there's people who do support, there's people who write documentation, there's people who organize events, so whatever you feel like your talent in the world is either that you have or that you want to cultivate.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A broadened contribution framework that highlights non-code paths (translation, support, docs, events) as first-class ways to participate.

quotes.topic_title: AI agents, security scanning, and maintenance mindset
quotes.text: But I think over the next five years it definitely approaches maybe a majority.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A concrete adoption forecast practitioners can use for planning AI-assisted development workflows and governance.

quotes.topic_title: AI agents, security scanning, and maintenance mindset
quotes.text: So, that's where when you hear about security issues with WordPress, it's very rarely in core anymore.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A counterintuitive security takeaway: the biggest risk in open ecosystems often shifts from core to extensions, changing where to focus controls.

quotes.topic_title: AI agents, security scanning, and maintenance mindset
quotes.text: It's impossible for humans to review that, so we kind of rely on developers to review that and manage.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A practical scaling reality that motivates automated scanning and process design rather than manual review as the primary defense.

quotes.topic_title: AI agents, security scanning, and maintenance mindset
quotes.text: As everyone knows, just writing the code is just one part of it. It's maintaining it that really becomes the life cycle of it.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A maintenance-first mental model for product and engineering teams to prioritize long-term ownership over initial build speed.

quotes.topic_title: AI agents, security scanning, and maintenance mindset
quotes.text: it's actually kind of going back to basics, back to core, and improving all of those kind of nooks and crannies of the user experience, and also ruthlessly editing and cutting as much as possible, because we just launched a lot of stuff over the past 21 years that maybe is not as relevant today or it doesn't need to be there.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Actionable product strategy: pay down UX/tech debt by systematically polishing neglected areas and deleting outdated surface area.

quotes.topic_title: Building WordPress as a movement and platform moat
quotes.text: So, if there's something unique I have for your audience, I would say it's don't just build a product, build a movement.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A clear north-star framing for community-led products: optimize for belief and participation, not just features.

quotes.topic_title: Building WordPress as a movement and platform moat
quotes.text: And to the extent that we've been successful, I think it's that we give people something to believe in, a philosophy, a worldview.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Highlights that durable communities form around shared identity and values, not only utility.

quotes.topic_title: Building WordPress as a movement and platform moat
quotes.text: The core features of a CMS, you can kind of write with a few developers in a few weeks or something. It's not... It's basically CRUD operations, but to replicate those 60,000 plugins and themes, gosh, no one's done it. That's a huge moat.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A concrete moat model: ecosystems (plugins/themes) are far harder to copy than core product functionality.

quotes.topic_title: Building WordPress as a movement and platform moat
quotes.text: And a true platform, it's when your ecosystem makes more money than the core does.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A crisp litmus test for whether you’ve built a real platform versus a product with integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Building WordPress as a movement and platform moat
quotes.text: And again, you don't have freedom unless you're building on open source.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A contrarian warning about dependency risk: open source reduces the chance of platform rug-pulls.

quotes.topic_title: WP Engine conflict: trademarks, product changes, lawsuit
quotes.text: And as you know, if you don't protect a trademark, you lose it.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A crisp reminder that brand/trademark stewardship is an active responsibility, not a passive asset.

quotes.topic_title: WP Engine conflict: trademarks, product changes, lawsuit
quotes.text: And when we do surveys, we'd find that 20, 30, 40% of people thought they were officially associated because how they were using our logo and presenting the brand and everything like that was very confusing to people.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how brand presentation can materially distort user perception and create support/UX fallout.

quotes.topic_title: WP Engine conflict: trademarks, product changes, lawsuit
quotes.text: So, a cool part about WordPress that... actually one of my favorite features, is every change to every single post or page is saved forever, just like Wikipedia. So, if you make a mistake, you can always undo it. And of course, as building a great product, that sort of user safety of an undo is so critical.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: Highlights a product mental model: “undo” and reversibility are core UX safety rails worth protecting.

quotes.topic_title: WP Engine conflict: trademarks, product changes, lawsuit
quotes.text: But to save money, they actually turned us off, so they broke the undo feature in WordPress to essentially save money.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A specific example of cost-cutting that degrades user experience by removing safety mechanisms.

quotes.topic_title: WP Engine conflict: trademarks, product changes, lawsuit
quotes.text: But one thing, if you're really open and open source, sometimes you have to stand up the bullies, and you have to fight to protect your open source ideals.
quotes.speaker: Matt Mullenweg
quotes.context: A counterintuitive leadership stance: openness can require confrontation to prevent exploitation of the system.
